content.description: <math alttext="2 N O, gas plus 2 H 2, gas reacts to produce, N 2, gas plus 2 H 2 O, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mi>NO</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>â†’</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>
content.question: The rate law for the reaction represented is <math alttext="rate equals, k times the molar concentration of N O, squared, times the molar concentration of H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>NO</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></math>. What happens to the rate of the reaction when the concentration of <math alttext="N O, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>NO</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is doubled and the concentration of <math alttext="H 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is halved?

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
